'''Direct Action and Democracy Today''' is a 2005 book by [[April Carter]]. In the book, Carter debates the nature and meaning of social and political protest and discusses the relationship between [[direct action]] and people's claims for greater [[democracy|democratic control]], not only against repressive regimes but also in [[liberal democracy|liberal parliamentary]] states.<ref>[http://bookshop.blackwell.co.uk/jsp/id/Direct_Action_and_Democracy_Today/9780745629353 Direct Action and Democracy Today] Polity Press, ISBN 0-7456-2935-0 (Hardback)</ref>
Carter is clearly supportive of direct action, but her analysis is based on logic and evidence rather than advocacy. Her assessments suggest that theorists have not been paying enough attention to the challenge posed by direct action, a challenge to both systems of [[Power (sociology)|power]] and the ideas that legitimate them.<ref>[http://www.uow.edu.au/arts/sts/bmartin/pubs/06BRjpr.html A review by [[Brian Martin (professor)|Brian Martin]] published in ''Journal of Peace Research'',] volume 43, number 4, July 2006, p. 492.</ref>
